instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.LP8550: What is LP8550? This is an LED driver responsible for creating the backlight on the LCD screen of Macbooks from 2011 through 2015.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PP5V_S4RS3: What is PP5V_S4RS3? PP5V_S4RS3 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS? This power rail is PPBUS_G3H after going through a current sense resistor that sits between PPBUS_G3H & the input of PPBUS_G3H to circuitry that provides power for the CPU..
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL: What is PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL? This is the voltage coming directly from the charger after going through a transistor. .
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS? This is PPBUS_G3H after passing through a current sense resistor that splits it off from the rest of PPBUS_G3H. The purpose of this is so that we can measure how much current is flowing to this part of the machine..
definitions.P3V3S5_EN_R: What is P3V3S5_EN_R? P3V3S5_EN_R is an enable signal that turns on the PP3V3_S5 power rail.  Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. The _R means the signal is asserted when the voltage is high(3.3v). .
definitions.P5VS4RS3_EN_R: What is P5VS4RS3_EN_R? P5VS4RS3_EN_R is an enable signal that turns on the PP5V_S4RS3 power rail. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. The _R means the signal is asserted when the voltage is high(3.3v). .
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good” and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.SMC_DELAYED_PWRGD: What is SMC_DELAYED_PWRGD? SMC_DELAYED_PWRGD is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a pre-requisite for SYS_PWROK_R and PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK..
definitions.PM_S0_PGOOD: What is PM_S0_PGOOD?  PM_S0_PGOOD is created when CPUVR_PGOOD and ALL_SYS_PWRGD are present and branches off to become PM_PCH_PWROK. PM_S0_PGOOD and SMC_DELAYED_PWRGD are necessary to create SYS_PWROK_R and PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK .
definitions.CPUVR_PGOOD_R: What is CPUVR_PGOOD_R? CPUVR_PGOOD_R is a signal that comes from CPU_VR_EN that is necessary along with ALL_SYS_PWRGD to create PM_S0_PGOOD.
definitions.SYS_PWORK_R: What is SYS_PWORK_R? This is a typo of SYS_PWROK When you see SYS_PWORK_R, assume they meant to type SYS_PWROK.
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.P3V3SUS_EN: What is P3V3SUS_EN? P3V3SUS_EN is a signal that turns on the PP3V3_SUS power rail when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high..
definitions.SMC_LSOC_RST_L: What is SMC_LSOC_RST_L? SMC_LSOC_RST_L is a signal that comes out of the trackpad on Macbook Airs that can reset the SMC.  _L means whatever before the _L in the signal name is asserted when it is low voltage, such as 0.0v to 0.5v..
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SL_S4_L</SIGNAL> 0v.
threads.message:
History:  Dog piss on logic board (yes, customer admitted to dog piss). 

Was turning on but no backlight, had major damage to the backlight and intMD/lvds area.  Stripped the intMD/lvds connector and replaced all the components (fuse, 1012 caps, coil etc) until i got 0.542 diode mode reading on backlight output.  Checked for shorts to ground on all replaced components. <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP> feedback was fucked so ran a wire, that was all good.  

Plugged in AC (known good Apple original 85w) got fan spin for 2 seconds then powered off. Now when AC power applied machine does not spin fans or go on from S4 > S4 state.

Checked backlight fuse (still good), re-checked backlight area for shorts, still good.
Removed the backlight fuse to see if anything further up was causing it, but no change.

Then back to testing power rails (results below) i've tried to follow this back through the schematic as far as i can but i'm getting a bit lost. Here are the readings i have taken so far.


S5 rails

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL>  present
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> present
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS</SIGNAL> present
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL</SIGNAL> 16.6v present
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.3v present
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> 3.3v present

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> missing
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> missing

<CHIP>U8080</CHIP> 0v at pin 2/3 (enable pin)
5v present at pin 29 of <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>
<TRANSISTOR>Q7520</TRANSISTOR> pin 1/3 8.5v all other pins 0
<CHIP>U7501</CHIP> pin 4 <SIGNAL>P5VS4RS3_EN_R</SIGNAL> is 0v)
<CHIP>U7501</CHIP> pin 21 <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN_R</SIGNAL> is 3.4v

so i believe the problem is on <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> not turning P5VS4 on
<RESISTOR>R7551</RESISTOR> is showing as 0.5ohm
<CAPACITOR>C8175</CAPACITOR> appears to be missing from the board - is this so ?
<RESISTOR>R8177</RESISTOR> is missing also....
<RESISTOR>R8179</RESISTOR> is present on the board (<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>) and is 0v
<RESISTOR>R1461</RESISTOR> (<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> nearest SMC) 0v

<SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> is 3.4v at <CAPACITOR>C4834</CAPACITOR> and at <RESISTOR>R5170</RESISTOR>. 

I realise these <SIGNAL>PM_SL_S4_L</SIGNAL> issues are tricky but am hoping the Rossman / Duke gods can suggest anything that can help before i move on.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SL_S4_L</SIGNAL> 0v.
threads.message: Is <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> present, was there corrosion at all around the <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>/<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> areas? Corrosion on backlight area puts you close to corrosion on SMC area. What does J6100 look like?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SL_S4_L</SIGNAL> 0v.
threads.message:
Thank you Louis.

the dog piss was very localised in the LVDS area as far as i could see, but it made a right mess.

<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> measures  3.4v at <RESISTOR>R8141</RESISTOR>,  <RESISTOR>R8141</RESISTOR> measures 93K ohm (vs 100k on schematic so ok).

No corrosion around <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> that is obvious, here are the pin voltages / diode mode in case that helps

<CHIP>U1950</CHIP> 

pin       voltage   diode mode   rail

pin 1:       0v           0.411         <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>
pin 2:       0v           0.668        <SIGNAL>CPUVR_PGOOD_R</SIGNAL>
pin 3:       0v           0.646        <SIGNAL>SYS_PWORK_R</SIGNAL>
pin 4:       0v           0               GND
pin 5:       0v           0.634        <SIGNAL>PM_S0_PGOOD</SIGNAL>
pin 6:       0v           0.667        <SIGNAL>SMC_DELAYED_PWRGD</SIGNAL>
pin 7:       0v           0.635        <SIGNAL>PM_S0_PGOOD</SIGNAL>
pin 8:       3.42v      0.303        <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>


working backward from <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>

looked at <SIGNAL>CPUVR_PGOOD_R</SIGNAL>
<RESISTOR>R1951</RESISTOR> (not present)
<RESISTOR>R1955</RESISTOR> 0.03v either side resistance 10k ohms.
then noticed it says NO STUFF on schematic so presume that the only input to <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> is <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> as <SIGNAL>CPUVR_PGOOD_R</SIGNAL> is no stuff.

J6100 looked very clean but i have removed it anyway.

followed schematic back on <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> but this lead me to <CHIP>U8160</CHIP>, <RESISTOR>R8164</RESISTOR>-<RESISTOR>R8167</RESISTOR> but these seem to be produced when in an S0 state, which we are not in.

<RESISTOR>R5100</RESISTOR> <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is 3.42v

thank you again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SL_S4_L</SIGNAL> 0v.
threads.message:
Further testing:

<CHIP>U7501</CHIP> pin 12 is 3,42v
<SIGNAL>SMC_LSOC_RST_L</SIGNAL> =3.42v
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> 3.42v at <RESISTOR>R5100</RESISTOR> and at <RESISTOR>R7100</RESISTOR>
<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> <RESISTOR>R5185</RESISTOR> 3,42
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> is 3.42
<SIGNAL>SMC_CLK32K</SIGNAL> is 0v

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> is 0.7v not 3.42 at <RESISTOR>R6101</RESISTOR>
<CHIP>U8020</CHIP> area <CAPACITOR>C8020</CAPACITOR> PP3V3S present 3.39v
following back to <SIGNAL>P3V3SUS_EN</SIGNAL> 
<RESISTOR>R8190</RESISTOR> is 3.3v
pin 1 of <RESISTOR>R8020</RESISTOR> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS_FET_R</SIGNAL> 3.4v (not present resitor) 
looking at <CHIP>U6100</CHIP>
<RESISTOR>R6102</RESISTOR> 0v

am i following this in the right direction do you think ? is 0.7v at <RESISTOR>R6101</RESISTOR> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> due to <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> being low or could it be causing it. 
Could i jumper <RESISTOR>R8020</RESISTOR> pin 1 to <RESISTOR>R6101</RESISTOR> for testing ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SL_S4_L</SIGNAL> 0v.
threads.message: So <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> is present at <RESISTOR>R8020</RESISTOR>. It is not present at <RESISTOR>R6102</RESISTOR> so there must be a corroded trace somewhere. Run a wire from <RESISTOR>R8020</RESISTOR> to <RESISTOR>R6102</RESISTOR>.
